verses.text: Rehoboam went to Shechem, for all Israel had come to Shechem to make him king.
verses.comment: This verse aligns closely with the Hebrew text; 'all Israel' refers to the northern tribes as well.

verses.text: When Jeroboam the son of Nebat heard of it—for he was in Egypt, where he had fled from King Solomon—Jeroboam returned from Egypt.
verses.comment: Faithfully represents Jeroboam's situation as exile in Egypt.

verses.text: They sent and called him. So Jeroboam and all Israel came and said to Rehoboam,
verses.comment: Reflects the original order and meaning.

verses.text: "Your father made our yoke hard. Now, lighten the hard service and the heavy yoke your father put on us, and we will serve you."
verses.comment: "Made our yoke hard" corresponds to making their burdens heavier.

verses.text: He said to them, "Return to me after three days." So the people went away.
verses.comment: Slight difference from 'depart for three days' (1 Kings 12:5), but Shechem assembly context is the same.

verses.text: Then King Rehoboam consulted with the elders who had served his father Solomon while he was alive, saying, "How do you advise me to answer these people?"
verses.comment: Rehoboam consults advisors who served Solomon.

verses.text: They said to him, "If you will be good to these people and please them and speak kindly to them, they will be your servants forever."
verses.comment: Captures the idiom 'speak good words to them.'

verses.text: But he abandoned the counsel that the elders gave him, and consulted with the young men who had grown up with him and were with him.
verses.comment: No significant variance from original text.

verses.text: He said to them, "What do you advise, so that we may answer these people who have spoken to me, saying, 'Lighten the yoke your father put on us'?"

The young men who had grown up with him said to him, "Say this to the people who told you, 'Your father made our yoke heavy, but you lighten it for us'—say to them, 'My little finger is thicker than my father's waist.'"
verses.comment: Phrase translated as 'my little finger is thicker than my father's waist' is a literal rendering; an idiom for being harsher.

verses.text: Now, my father burdened you with a heavy yoke, but I will add to your yoke. My father disciplined you with whips, but I will discipline you with scorpions."
verses.comment: The Hebrew 'scorpions' likely refers to whips with metal spikes.

verses.text: So Jeroboam and all the people came to Rehoboam on the third day, as the king had said, 'Come back to me on the third day.'
verses.comment: Stays true to the narrative structure.

verses.text: The king answered them harshly, and he abandoned the advice of the elders.
verses.comment: The term 'harshly' is used for modern clarity.

verses.text: He spoke to them according to the advice of the young men, saying, "My father made your yoke heavy, but I will add to it. My father disciplined you with whips, but I will discipline you with scorpions."
verses.comment: Reiterates the earlier statement for emphasis.

verses.text: So the king did not listen to the people, for this turn of events was from God, that the LORD might fulfill his word, which he had spoken by Ahijah the Shilonite to Jeroboam the son of Nebat.
verses.comment: Clarifies that the division was God's will per prophetic word.

verses.text: When all Israel saw that the king did not listen to them, the people answered the king, "What share do we have in David? We have no inheritance in Jesse's son. Each to your tents, Israel! Look after your own house, David!" So all Israel went to their tents.
verses.comment: Renders the common ancient protest chant accurately.

verses.text: But as for the Israelites living in the cities of Judah, Rehoboam ruled over them.
verses.comment: Shortens 'children of Israel who lived in the cities of Judah' for clarity.

verses.text: Then King Rehoboam sent Hadoram, who was over the forced labor; but the Israelites stoned him to death. King Rehoboam quickly got into his chariot and fled to Jerusalem.
verses.comment: In Chronicles, the official's name is 'Hadoram' (not 'Adoram'); this is reflected in translation.

verses.text: So Israel has been in rebellion against the house of David to this day.
verses.comment: 'To this day' refers to the time of writing; in English, this maintains the sense of ongoing rebellion at the text's time.
